title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Close to the village stands Comrie House (Dundas, Bart.), on the east side of which the Lednoch Water flows into the Earn, and half a mile to the south are the remains of a Roman camp.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Comrie [Inn : Commercial] is pleasantly situated on the north bank of the river Earn, at its confluence with the Ruchill, and is by many supposed to have been the scene of the famous battle between Galgacus and Agricola.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The road now winds along the banks of the river Earn, through groves of lofty trees, presenting here and there broken glimpses of the ridges of these mountains.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Accordingly, taking with them a boat from Lnch Tay, they launched it on Locli Earn, and arriving at the den at dead of night, fell upon the robbers by surprise,  and put them all to the sword.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The Earn with its tributaries Pvuchill, Ruthven.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Lochs Tay, Earn, and Dochart, in the centre of the county.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Its drainage is 2283 square miles, and its mean discharge below the junction of the Earn has been ascertained by Mr. David Stevenson to be 273,117 cubic feet per minute.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: At the foot of the vale of Strathearn, it receives on its right bank its last great tributary, the Earn, and gradually expanding its waters, it flows in a north-easterly direction past Newburgh, where it assumes the apj^earance of a firth or estuary.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: Up at all hours, out all day and all night, often without food, — with nothing but the unfailing pipe, — there he was, stalking the deer in Glen Tilt or across the Gaick moors, or rousing before daybreak the undaunted otter among the alders of the Earn, the Isla, or the Almond ; and if in his pursuit, which was fell as any hound's, he got his hand into the otter's grip, and had its keen teeth meeting in his palm, he let it have its will till the pack came up, — no flinching,  almost as if without the sense of pain.

title: Spare hours.
author: Brown, John
snippet: Up at all hours, out all day and all night, often without food, — with nothing but the unfailing pipe, — there he was, stalking the deer in Glen Tilt or across the Gaick moors, or rousing before daybreak the undaunted otler among the alders of the Earn, the Isla, or the Almond ; and if in his pursuit, which was fell as any hound's, he got his hand into the otter's grip, and had its keen teeth meeting in his palm, he let it have its will till the pack came up, — no flinching,  almost as if without the sense of pain.

title: Braes o' Balquhidder. A novel
author: Aytoun, Douglas.
snippet: Further on still, they met the Earn once more on itswinding way, ' midst muirs and mosses many o '; withfresh treasures in the form of picturesque boulders;curiously twisted dwarf trees, casting weird, witch-likeshadows on the grass ; and a wealth of ferns, wild shrubs,and modest-eyed flowerets that seemed afraid to peep upat the passers by.

title: Braes o' Balquhidder. A novel
author: Aytoun, Douglas.
snippet: Thetravellers drove that forenoon as far as the great glen ofthe Earn ; where was pointed out the protruding pieceof rock on which his Satanic Eminence is said to haveplaced his right foot—while the lava was yet in a semiliquid state—and there left the lasting imprint of thatmember; the great-toe marks being a perpetual sourceof terror to all the bairns of the country side.

title: Braes o' Balquhidder. A novel
author: Aytoun, Douglas.
snippet: Being the highest of the Grampian range, the prospectis at once commanding and fraught with revelations—the Strath of the Earn, St. Fillans, Comrie, Crieff, Ardvoirlich, Glen Artney, and innumerable points of intereston every side.
